item.title: GOP Health Bill Could Let Insurers Cap Spending On Expensive Patients
item.description: June 30, 2017 - Current law requires all health insurance sold on the exchanges to cover 10 essential benefits — with no annual or lifetime limits to reimbursement. But the GOP plan might let states reinstate limits.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - Current law requires all health insurance sold on the exchanges to cover 10 essential benefits — with no annual or lifetime limits to reimbursement. But the GOP plan might let states reinstate limits. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/30/534773322/gop-health-bill-could-let-insurers-cap-spending-on-expensive-patients

item.title: Government Researchers Plan Response To Rising Rates Of Black Lung Disease
item.description: June 30, 2017 - Government researchers met in West Virginia this week in response to an NPR investigation and federal study showing much higher rates of the most serious stages of the coal miners' disease black lung.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - Government researchers met in West Virginia this week in response to an NPR investigation and federal study showing much higher rates of the most serious stages of the coal miners' disease black lung. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/30/535059200/government-researchers-plan-response-to-rising-rates-of-black-lung-disease

item.title: GOP Lawmakers Face Political Risks In Supporting Unpopular Health Care Bill
item.description: June 30, 2017 - Congressional Republicans say the political risks of failing to make good on their promise to dismantle the Affordable Care Act outweigh the risks of passing an unpopular bill.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - Congressional Republicans say the political risks of failing to make good on their promise to dismantle the Affordable Care Act outweigh the risks of passing an unpopular bill. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/30/535059169/gop-lawmakers-face-political-risks-in-supporting-unpopular-health-care-bill

item.title: For Newborns Exposed To Opioids, Health Issues May Be The Least Of Their Problems
item.description: June 30, 2017 - Dr. Joshua Sharfstein says worry less about the short-term withdrawal symptoms of babies exposed to opioids in the womb, and much more about the lives and mothers they go home to.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - Dr. Joshua Sharfstein says worry less about the short-term withdrawal symptoms of babies exposed to opioids in the womb, and much more about the lives and mothers they go home to. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/30/534911289/for-newborns-exposed-to-opioids-health-issues-may-be-the-least-of-their-problems

item.title: How To Stop The World's Worst Cholera Outbreak
item.description: June 30, 2017 - There are more than 200,000 cases in Yemen, a war-ravaged country whose health system is collapsing. We asked specialists what needs to happen to bring the disease under control.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - There are more than 200,000 cases in Yemen, a war-ravaged country whose health system is collapsing. We asked specialists what needs to happen to bring the disease under control. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/30/534873405/how-to-stop-the-worlds-worst-cholera-outbreak

item.title: Syrian Civilians Exposed To Sarin In April Attack, International Watchdog Says
item.description: June 30, 2017 - The finding is consistent with experts' suspicions. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons stopped short of saying who was responsible. The U.S. blames the Syrian regime.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - The finding is consistent with experts' suspicions. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons stopped short of saying who was responsible. The U.S. blames the Syrian regime. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/06/30/534983929/syrian-civilians-exposed-to-sarin-in-april-attack-international-watchdog-says

item.title: Will My High Premiums Go Down? More Q&A About The GOP Health Plan
item.description: June 30, 2017 - We're answering more questions about the Republican plan to overhaul the Affordable Care Act, including what the proposed changes would mean for healthy young people and for taxes.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - We're answering more questions about the Republican plan to overhaul the Affordable Care Act, including what the proposed changes would mean for healthy young people and for taxes. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/30/534906065/will-my-high-premiums-go-down-more-q-a-about-the-gop-health-plan

item.title: Obamacare Has Problems. The Senate Health Care Bill Doesn't Solve Them, Experts Say
item.description: June 30, 2017 - We asked top health care experts to tell us America's biggest health care problems. Then we asked: Does the current Republican plan fix them? For the most part, the answer was no.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 30, 2017 - We asked top health care experts to tell us America's biggest health care problems. Then we asked: Does the current Republican plan fix them? For the most part, the answer was no. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/30/534756511/senate-bill-leaves-key-problems-with-health-care-system-unresolved

item.title: Tumor Test Helps Identify Which Breast Cancers Don't Require Extra Treatment
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Researchers say the test, which measures gene activity, can help avoid "overtreating" tumors that are not life-threatening. It might allow some patients to avoid radiation and chemotherapy.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Researchers say the test, which measures gene activity, can help avoid "overtreating" tumors that are not life-threatening. It might allow some patients to avoid radiation and chemotherapy. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/29/534882955/tumor-test-helps-identify-which-breast-cancers-dont-require-extra-treatment

item.title: As Opioid Overdoses Bleed City's Budget, Councilman Proposes Stopping Treatment
item.description: June 29, 2017 - "If we don't do anything, the city's going to run out of money," Middletown City Councilman Dan Picard says. The epidemic costs the city 10 percent of its annual tax revenue.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - "If we don't do anything, the city's going to run out of money," Middletown City Councilman Dan Picard says. The epidemic costs the city 10 percent of its annual tax revenue. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534916080/ohio-town-struggles-to-afford-life-saving-drug-for-opioid-overdoses

item.title: Democrats Push Back On Senate Republican Health Care Bill
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Many Democrats were encouraged that Republicans had to push off their vote on a Senate bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, in the midst of vocal opposition from the left.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Many Democrats were encouraged that Republicans had to push off their vote on a Senate bill to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, in the midst of vocal opposition from the left. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534916024/democrats-push-back-on-senate-republican-health-care-bill

item.title: The Plague Is Back, This Time In New Mexico
item.description: June 29, 2017 - In medieval times, they called it "the black death." It's still around, routinely cropping up in the U.S. This time, the New Mexico Department of Health reports three cases.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - In medieval times, they called it "the black death." It's still around, routinely cropping up in the U.S. This time, the New Mexico Department of Health reports three cases. http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/06/29/534863486/the-bubonic-plague-is-back-this-time-in-new-mexico

item.title: What Happens When The Heroin Epidemic Hits Small Town America?
item.description: June 29, 2017 - West Virginia has the highest drug overdose death rate in the country. New Yorker writer Margaret Talbot interviewed addicts, their families and health professionals to understand why.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - West Virginia has the highest drug overdose death rate in the country. New Yorker writer Margaret Talbot interviewed addicts, their families and health professionals to understand why. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534868012/what-happens-when-the-heroin-epidemic-hits-small-town-america

item.title: C. Diff Infections Are Falling, Thanks To Better Cleaning And Fewer Antibiotics
item.description: June 29, 2017 - The bacterium C. difficile causes one of the most common infections in hospitals and nursing homes. After climbing for decades, the rate of new infections is now falling.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - The bacterium C. difficile causes one of the most common infections in hospitals and nursing homes. After climbing for decades, the rate of new infections is now falling. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/06/29/534870581/c-diff-infections-are-falling-thanks-to-better-cleaning-and-fewer-antibiotics

item.title: With The Senate's Health Care Vote Delayed, What's Next For Democrats?
item.description: June 29, 2017 - Do Democrats want to work with Republicans to make the health bill better? Rachel Martin talks to Tom Perez, chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: June 29, 2017 - Do Democrats want to work with Republicans to make the health bill better? Rachel Martin talks to Tom Perez, chairman of the Democratic National Committee. http://www.npr.org/2017/06/29/534848770/with-the-senates-health-care-vote-delayed-whats-next-for-democrats
